channel.title: Readings on ESPM 288
channel.description: Recent content in Readings on ESPM 288

item.description: DataCamp Syllabus Git, Greg Wilson RStudio IDE, Part I, RStudio IDE, Part II Reports with RMarkdown, Garrett Grolemund Data wrangling, David Robinson dplyr intro, Garrett Grolemund Writing Functions in R, Hadley Wickham

item.title: Geospatial Reading - I
item.description: You’ve probably noticed that our textbook doesn’t have any section on geospatial data. Most exsiting resources on geospatial data in R still cover the older sp library, including the classic Applied Spatial Data Analysis in R (physical) textbook (by authors of sp and related packages, who are also authors of sf). The under-development version of an upcoming textbook, Geocomputation with R, aims to provide a more thorough treatment of the latest iteration on spatial data in R, including the sf package and tidyverse-style programming.

item.title: Getting help
item.description: R’s Documentation Getting Help Guide 1.6: Getting Help

item.title: R Markdown Basics
item.description: Watch Reports with RMarkdown, Garrett Grolemund Read: Introduction [r4ds-27.1] R Markdown basics [r4ds-27.2] Code chunks [r4ds-27.4] Reference R Markdown Cheat Sheet R Markdown Reference Guide

item.description: In advance of Thursday’s class (2017-09-07), please read: Data Visualization Intro,Section 3.4 - Section 3.6

item.title: Reading for 2017-09-07
item.description: In advance of Thursday’s class (2017-09-14), please read: Tidy data: 12.1 - 12.3. Of particular interest is getting used to the “tidy structure” of fig 12.1, and the use of the gather() function.

item.description: For Thursday’s class, please read the following two short sections: 6. Workflow: scripts, and 8. Workflow: projects

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-03
item.description: Please read Chapter 21.1 to 21.4 on iteration

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-05
item.description: Today’s class will introduce the basic idea of an R package as a fundamental unit for sharing re-usable R functions. We will re-organize our population dynamics assignment repo into the structure required for an R package. While writing a minimal R package is really pretty simple, R packages are still considered an advanced topic and rightly the subject of completely separate books. We recommend Hadley Wickham’s Writing R Packages which is available in press or online for more detailed reading.

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-10
item.description: Today’s class will introduce a new section on fisheries collapse. We will also be diving into data manipulation in earnest. Make sure to read or re-familiarize yourself with the basic dplyr verbs filter, arrange, select, and mutate, Sections 5.1 - 5.5

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-12
item.description: More dplyr: working with grouped data using group_by and summarize: Sections 5.6 - 5.7

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-17
item.description: Read the opening sections of chapter 13 on Relational Data: Sections 13.1 - 13.4.1.

item.title: Reading for 2017-10-26
item.description: Install Docker (Community Edition, free & open source) for your laptop Launch the Docker command line, and run: docker pull rocker/tidyverse to download the image we’ll be using in class. This is a large download (689 MB), so please attempt this ahead of time since we won’t all be able to download it at once. If either of these steps do not work for you, don’t worry, we should be able to fix any special cases in class.

item.title: Setup
item.description: Watch RStudio IDE, Part I, Garrett Grolemund Read Prerequisites Running R code RStudio Cheat sheet (for reference) Style guide Consistent style is an important element of communication and collaboration. Please review sections 1 Files and 2 Syntax. Most Syntax conventions can be automatically checked with lintr::lint("assignment.Rmd").
